body_html:
+1 if you're going to go as far as tfcompile; consider just using C++ to interface with your training loop.

alternatively, write a TF C++ op wrapper that communicates with a mujoco session via server/client calls; and then your multiple interactions can be subsumied within a tf.while_loop.

another alternative might be to use session.partial_run to avoid the cost of copying data back and forth between python/C++.
body_text:
+1 if you're going to go as far as tfcompile; consider just using C++ to interface with your training loop.
alternatively, write a TF C++ op wrapper that communicates with a mujoco session via server/client calls; and then your multiple interactions can be subsumied within a tf.while_loop.
another alternative might be to use session.partial_run to avoid the cost of copying data back and forth between python/C++.
body:
+1 if you're going to go as far as tfcompile; consider just using C++ to interface with your training loop.

alternatively, write a TF C++ op wrapper that communicates with a mujoco session via server/client calls; and then your multiple interactions can be subsumied within a tf.while_loop.

another alternative might be to use session.partial_run to avoid the cost of copying data back and forth between python/C++.
